question: Question_02_(a)
sols:
We first solve the indefinite integral, using the trigonometric identity
$\sin(2x) = 2\sin(x)\cos(x)$:

\begin{align*} \int \sin(\pi x)\cos(\pi x)\,dx &= \int \frac12 \sin(2\pi x)\,dx \\
&=-\frac1{4\pi}\cos(2\pi x) + C. \end{align*}

Therefore

\begin{align*} I_1 &= \int_{1/2}^1 \sin(\pi x)\cos(\pi x)\,dx \\
&= \left.\frac{-1}{4\pi}\cos(2\pi x)\right|_{1/2}^1 \\
&= \frac{-1}{4\pi} \cos(2\pi) + \frac1{4\pi} \cos(\pi) \\
&= -\frac1{4\pi} - \frac1{4\pi}Â = -\frac1{2\pi}. \end{align*}

Alternatively, substitute $u = \sin(\pi x).$ Then
$du = \pi \cos(\pi x)dx$, when $x=1/2$ then $u = \sin(\pi/2) = 1$, and
when $x=1$ then $u = \sin(\pi) = 0.$ Therefore

\begin{align*} I_1 &= \int_{1/2}^1 \sin(\pi x)\cos(\pi x)\,dx \\
&= \int_1^0 u \cos(\pi x)\frac{du}{\pi \cos(\pi x)} \\
&= \frac1{\pi} \int_1^0 u\,du \\
&= \left.\frac1{2\pi}u^2\right|_1^0 \\
&= - \frac1{2\pi}.\end{align*}
hints: Use a trigonometric identity to rewrite the integrand.
